learning_outcomes.description: Implement real-world solutions using the design principles of embedded systems and system interfacing
Use the principles of data encoding to implement robust communication channels
Analyse an embedded system's performance and infer potential problems
Maximise the performance and efficiency of an embedded system design implementation
Build and test software library sub-modules and hardware sub-modules for embedded systems
Employ a real-time operating system with bare metal C programming libraries to develop functional embedded systems.
List the technology and design methods used in real-world engineering.
Illustrate and outline the details of your embedded systems designs.

assessments.category: Computer Code, Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Notebook/ Logbook, Practical/ Demonstration
assessments.task_description:
All stage specifications are available on Blackboard. There are seven assessed stages (Stages 1 to 7) and one non-assessed stage (Stage 0). Stages 1 to 7 are worth 6% each. Stage 0 is not assessed. The total mark is calculated as the sum of the five highest stage marks.

For each prac session, the first 2 hours are for working on the stage and the last hour is for marking and feedback.

Demonstration (in-person)

The stage must be demonstrated (in person) at the end of the first 2 hours of your assigned prac session, in the same week as the stage is due. Failure to demonstrate your stage will result in no marks being recorded for the demonstration, Blackboard submission, or code.

Report

Each stage requires a report to be completed and submitted at the end of the first 2 hours of your assigned prac session, in the same week as the stage is due. The report paper booklet must be submitted by giving it to the assessing teaching staff member in the prac venue (lab). The report paper booklet must not be removed by the student from the prac venue.

Use of AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Stage code must be submitted to the code repository at the end of the first two hours of your prac session, using git push. Code submissions made with only git commit will not be accepted. You must demonstrate your stage at the end of the first two hours of your prac session. The report paper booklet must also be submitted at the end of the first two hours of your prac session. The report paper booklet must be submitted by giving it to the assessing teaching staff member in the prac venue (lab). The report paper booklet must not be removed by the student from the prac venue.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.category: Computer Code, Notebook/ Logbook, Practical/ Demonstration, Project
assessments.task_description:
Project Milestone - as specified in the Project sheet, available on Blackboard.  

Diagrams must be submitted to Blackboard by the due date and time.

Demonstration (in-person) - your lab session

You must attend your session in the due week to do your demo. Failure to demonstrate your milestone will result in no marks being recorded.

Use of AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: All project milestone code must be submitted to the code repository by the due date. The diagrams must be submitted to Blackboard by the due date. Code must be submitted to the code repository by the due date, using git push. Code submissions made with only git commit, will not be accepted. Demonstrations are completed in your assigned prac.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

Use of AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: All project code must be submitted to the code repository by the due date. All diagrams and other assessment must be submitted to BlackBoard. Code must be submitted to the code repository by the due date, using git push. Code submissions made with only git commit, will not be accepted.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.

assessments.task_description:
The final exam assesses all aspects of the course.

Use of AI

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 12(23 Feb - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Lectures cover topics in embedded system design, interfacing, realtime operating systems and communications. The lectures are synchronised, as much as possible, with topics covered in the pracs and project.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lectures Lectures cover topics in embedded system design, interfacing, realtime operating systems and communications. The lectures are synchronised, as much as possible, with topics covered in the pracs and project.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 11(23 Feb - 17 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Weekly Applied Class

The weekly applied class session will present content related to the stages and revise lecture material through revision questions.
learning_activities.topic_description: Weekly Applied Class The weekly applied class session will present content related to the stages and revise lecture material through revision questions.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 8(23 Feb - 26 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Project Stage Sessions

Weekly laboratory development, consultation and feedback sessions with tasks specified according to the project stages. Software modules developed in these sessions are to be reused and integrated in the project.
learning_activities.topic_description: Project Stage Sessions Weekly laboratory development, consultation and feedback sessions with tasks specified according to the project stages. Software modules developed in these sessions are to be reused and integrated in the project.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 9 To Week 13(27 Apr - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Project

The Project covers embedded system interfacing and realtime operating system (RTOS) development. The project is an integration of software modules developed in the stage sessions. Project specification is published on blackboard before the start of the project.
learning_activities.topic_description: Project The Project covers embedded system interfacing and realtime operating system (RTOS) development. The project is an integration of software modules developed in the stage sessions. Project specification is published on blackboard before the start of the project.
